name: Missing Translation
description: Lost in a weird city in the middle of the desert and surrounded by strange creatures that keep staring at you. This is a game about exploring the unknown and solving puzzles... lots of them! Don't be fooled by the looks, this isn't a point & click adventure.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 or newer Processor: 2 GHz dual core Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Hardware Accelerated Graphics with dedicated memory Storage: 100 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Charming puzzle game with seemingly challenging obstacles, worth the try if you're into a causual astmosphere. There's 3 tiers of puzzles, each with 25 in them. Nothing super challenging, just tedious.   Game also taught me white on black is not okay. (puzzle tier 3 if you're interested in the joke)
The game had a great story. The puzzles were addicting and fun. Even though it's a 1 hour story, it still was great.

This is a fun puzzle game with 75 puzzles total. The pixelated art style in grayscale combined with the nice music is calming as you go through the little world. The world design is very pleasing; I enjoyed the little cats sitting on the buildings and the strange inhabitants of the town.  I strongly recommend this game, and given that it is free you should certainly give it a go.
this game is fun i love it

What's all the hype about learning a new language? There's no language here to be learned. You win the game by completing 75 puzzles. Most of them are almost identical and it's quite easy to grasp the logic. The rest can be solved quite quickly by random clicking. All of them are rather boring and unsatisfying to solve.  The graphics would be acceptable if there was any sort of depth to the game aside from the puzzles, but there isn't. It's clear that the artist put lots of good work into creating environments that will never need to be looked at. And the puzzles themselves were not paid any particular attention, even though they are the core of the game.   Some parts of the map appear as if they can be unlocked as the game progresses, but that's just to trick the player into thinking there's more.    All in all, you essentially get what you pay for: nothing.
Great music!  and Compeletely Free! Very well done pixel art grayscale graphics Interesting concept, no words. Omnilingual game.
Close to being good. It's rather relaxing, but sadly the puzzles themselves are rather boring and repetitive. I would have preferred some more exploring of the world and the language in the game.
I finished the game in an hour and i really like the idea of the game even though it's really short :( I love the puzzles and the thinking you have to do for this game and it's free!!  9/10
If you love puzzles its pretty fun.
Great free game without any language barriers (and nice puzzles) !
It's a fun puzzle game to play for about an hour. (even though I didn't really get into the language that much just the numbers)
Simple gameplay and high fun factor. Contains some good brain teasers as well ‚àö

If you're looking for a way to unwind or just some simple puzzles to take your mind off things, give this game a try. There are three sets of 25 puzzles (as others have noted) that become increasingly difficult. You may get hooked up on a few but none are really so hard that you will become frustrated.

It's not too bad, but there's a lot of really good puzzle games out there if you're looking for one.
I don't finish games usually, but I did finish this one so this means this is kinda special to me.   With more length this would be an amazing paid game.

I really like the concept behind this game, and the design is very good too. Like, can I throw someone some money for this?  My cat, however, does not like the game. This was how I played the first set of puzzles:  Puzzles 1-3: 'Oh hey, the screen is doing something! How did I solve that?' Puzzles 4-6: 'Ohhh I got it now! Let's go!' Puzzle 7: 'Dude, I'm gonna own this set of puzzles.'Cat jumps onto my lap. Puzzle 8: Solve puzzle easily, cat is content to sit in my lap and purr, occasionally butting his head against my face. Puzzles 9-10: 'Oh, I might have to start thinking about these puzzles soon.' Puzzle 11: 'Okay, I got this...' Cat hops up on table, walks around perimeter of table, gets back in my lap. Puzzle 13: I start not getting the puzzles right on the first try. Cat keeps repeating table-circle-lap thing. Puzzle 17: Am having to really think about these puzzles and try a few times. Cat doesn't know if he wants to be on my lap, on the table, or both. Puzzle 18: Cat is meowing from my lap for attention. 100 percent of it. Puzzle 19: Throw cat off my lap to work on puzzle. Cat jumps back up. Puzzle 20: 'Gonna finish this, yeah!' Cat is insistently banging his face against mine regardless of response in order to get attention. Puzzle 24: Cat gives up after repeatedly insisting that 'Meaaah' and 'mrrrah', goes to living room. Puzzle 25: Victory!  Start typing review of game: cat pukes on living room rug.  Logging off for the day to give my needy cat the attention he wants.

Gameplay: <1h Real gameplay: <10min, 5min for each puzzle  After the first glance of the conception of the 2 puzzles (right there are only 2 because the 1st 'puzzle' with 4 buttons merely counts as one), the rest consists only of 25 times of plain duplication.  Didn't find the audio option. No choice other than putting up with the soundtracks. Indeed some of them sound really good, but the 'infinite loop' thing is as depressing as the 25 duplications of puzzle.
Very dissapointing, only three minigames, two of which are really tedious (and there are 25 levels for each!). There is no story and the idea of missing translation is just pointless and unnecessary.
A really good game full of puzzles! Besides its black-and-white theme is very artistic! GG developers, GG!!
Puzzles are boring, story is meh, graphics are meh, animation was meh.  Entire thing was meh.
So. Many. Puzzles.  + : puzzles, puzzles, more puzzles, fun, story, free, way to answer  - : puzzles might seem repetitive  8/10 would puzzle again

Short but very cool puzzle game. Figure out how to communicate with the people in this place and solve puzzles as you go.

Oh man, I really really wanted to love this game. The promise of a new language via pictograms really got me interested, and I began the game eagerly. Sadly enough, the game had about 10 'words' or concepts in shapes you could make on an Android lock screen. They aren't bad, but they're so limiting when there's no point to learning them. There's only a single puzzle that requires any understanding of them and that one isn't even words, it's based on numbers.   It's a remarkably detailed world for being greyscale, so it was nice to look at. The music was fantastic, but the loop was surprisingly short. I know I heard the same music sequence multiple times and I played almost two hours. That isn't a long time, but the music shouldn't be so obviously repetitive.   The entire 'plot' of the game is in two cut scenes, one at the beginning and one at the end. That's it. They're maybe two minutes combined, so plot is thin on the ground. This game focuses mostly on its puzzles, though. They're simplistic, and, honestly, boring. The first few levels of the puzzles (there are 3 types and 25 levels each) were interesting because you had to figure out what to do and once you had it, there was a definite 'Aha!' moment. But after you understood, it was easy, almost painfully so.  This game could really use more to it. It's a great base, and honestly, I have no idea why it won all those awards. It isn't terrible, per se, but it feels like a demo, not the full game. If you were interested in the language part, don't even bother. If you like puzzles, don't bother. If you want plot-- that's right, don't bother. It just isn't worth your time investment when it gives you nothing in return. If it had more language like it promised, it might be worth it, but as it is, it just isn't.

Please click read more to see full review of Missing Translation. I talk about lots of things from genre, game play, graphics, cons/let down, and more. If you also find this helpful or not leave a rating!  Overview: Missing Translation is a pixel, puzzle, indie game, that‚Äôs free to play and over all is very good. It offers a good hour or two, depending on how good you are at solving puzzles. The game has a unique story, which I found to be interesting. The game play is simple and the puzzles are pretty simple, a little hard towards the end of them. The graphics fit well with the game, I couldn‚Äôt see it be anything other than pixels. Some other things included are steam achievements, 6 in total which are all possible to get in one play though. I personally was able to get all 6 and I can now add this game to my 100% completed list. Lastly, there‚Äôs no language needed to understand this game, it‚Äôs all symbols, so anyone can just download it and play.  Genre: Missing Translation is a puzzle game that offers 3 different types of puzzle for you to complete. Each type has 25 puzzles you can complete, this totals to 75 puzzles to complete. The puzzles are pretty simple and start off easy at first, then they start to get harder and harder towards then end. I personally liked all 3 different types of puzzles and I was able to complete at 75 puzzles in one play though. The only downfall I could find to these puzzles is it‚Äôs a bit repetitive towards the end and they could off added some more. Also if you‚Äôre not good at puzzles or just don‚Äôt have the patience to take your time and solve them, you might find the last few to be a bit hard. But other than those couple reasons it‚Äôs a very good free to play puzzle game.  Graphics: Missing Translation is a pixel and black and white game at its heart. The graphics work very well with the game and I couldn‚Äôt see the game using any other type of graphics. I love the graphics personally and I couldn‚Äôt find any flaws with it. Overall the pixels and the black and white theme really work well with the game and add to its charm.  Game play: The game play for Missing Translation is really simple, first move around the area you‚Äôre in, then just come across doors that take you to puzzles. After that you complete the puzzles and move on to the next ones, very simple. As you do this, the story will revival intersecting plots in its self. I won‚Äôt talk about the story; due to it being simple and you should download the game and just see it for you. The controls are simple, just moving around and a activate key. Overall the game play is simple and works very well for this game.  Content: Missing Translation offers about 1 to 2 hours of game play, depending on how good at puzzle games you are. There are 3 different types of puzzles, totaling up to 75 puzzles, for you to complete. There are also 6 steam achievements that you can get; these are all possible to get on your first play though.   Cons/Let Downs: Missing Translation is a fast game that only offers a couple of hours at most. The only thing this game lacks is content. Without more content there‚Äôs really no point to replay it after you beat the game and get all the steam achievements. Other than that little thing, this game is a little gem.  Would I recommend this game? I would totally recommend this game to anyone who likes puzzle games or indie games that offer a new type of game you haven‚Äôt seen before. If like puzzles you are going to love this game. Also if you are looking for a free game to get all the steam achievements for, this is a great game to do that with. I would recommend this game for anyone looking for a great free to play game!
If you like puzzles, this is a fun little free game to play. I had fun trying to figure out the language the most.

Missing Translation, a game that has been in my library for ages and that I have finally got around to.  Pros: -Pixel art and black & white style is appealing -Soundtrack is great -Challenging puzzles, but not frustrating -No dialogue, which offers the player a chance to interpret and challenge them to think about it in their own way  Cons: -Bit short  Overall, this is a great F2P title. Worth a look. 8/10

It is really simple and easy to learn.  The b&w simple graphics looks cute and it has a weird atmosphere all over. All you need to know is shown on the first seconds of the game: you were abducted and need to find parts of a machine to go home. As you search for the machine parts you need to solve puzzles, and each puzzle makes it clear what you need to do. Overall you got 3 kinds of puzzle and 25 levels in each plus an extra in decoding symbols (find the scientist) Aparently there might be some extra content in the future but for nopw it can be finished in under 2 hours (and I did look a lot around trying to see if there was something else). The idea is nice but it gets a bit repetitive as you advance on each puzzle, maybe more kinds and less lvls could be more fun.  So if you like puzzles and paterns go for it.

This game is definitely worth spending time on There are three types of puzzles you go through, and each puzzle has 25 levels to it. None of the puzzles are actually hard though, yeah it took me a while to finish some of them but no, they were not hard at all. I easily give this game a 9/10, Awesome artwork, tedious puzzles, and a soundtrack I can listen to for a long time. -1 point for little context as to why the player must go through the puzzles, and a decent amount of walking is involved. Other than that, nicely done!

Fun little puzzle game. The puzzles were easy enough that I never felt the need to look up solutions for them but still provided some challenge. The third round that had the light/dark rotating puzzle (located farthest away from the start point) was the most challenging but still enjoyable.   The only downside for me is that the acheivement system is not working for Mac users so I wasn't able to get any achievements. While an enjoyable game I don't know if I would want to do a second play through of the same puzzles just to get the achievements when they become available.

Superb game!    Missing Translation  is a puzzle game that exercises your brain cells with three types of puzzles that has 25 respective levels. It's definitely challenging on the first few tries but it could get repetitive and dull afterwards. If you're looking for a hardcore puzzle session then this game may come up short for you. This is like a mini game that you can finish in an hour.  What makes this game superb, aside from the cool pixel art and music, is the 'decoding' part. You have to think to figure out, why is this game called Missing Translation? What are these symbols for? What the hell does this doctor dude want??   Finding out what the game truly wants to convey is definitely something.
+good puzzle +hidden language to be translated...even it's not needed to complete the game...
Pretty awesome little game! Nice music and pixel art! The puzzles get a bit repetitive but all in all entertainig.
Nice BGM Good puzzle Has a deep meaning behind of it 8/10

It's a good short game. The entire game is mainly solving puzzle, which is actually only 3 very similar styles, each with 25 levels. The exploration of learning the language of the locals, which is very limited, is entirely optional. The puzzles are not hard, at least for someone who often see these types of puzzles. However, repeatedly doing 25 levels each type is not really fun. Overall, this game has potential. If the developer explores more on the avenue of adventure and learning, and less on the repetition, and add more varieties on the types of puzzles, it could become a more interesting game.
doesn't take long to finish, puzzles are easy to solve. not much to do.
Great simple puzzle game. Take about an hour to finish, and I really liked it. This is another free game, so there is no reason not to at least try it.
